title: Chinese capital of pet toys faces harsh impact of the trade war
summary: Twenty years ago, Shuitou, a factory town in Zhejiang, had to close its 1,000 leather tanneries due to excessive pollution. Gradually repurposed into a global hub for pet accessories, it now faces a new threat from US tariffs.

title: Netanyahu instructs negotiators to continue steps to release Gaza hostages
summary: Meanwhile, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu made a rare visit to Gaza on Tuesday as the military pressed on with its air and ground assault against the Palestinian territory.

title: Zelensky says Ukraine and US are nearing a deal on strategic minerals
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky says talks with Washington on a long-delayed minerals agreement are making 'good progress,' with a deal potentially days away.

title: Arsenal knock out Real Madrid to reach Champions League semi-finals
summary: Arsenal beat Real Madrid 2-1 on Wednesday, with winger Gabriel Martinelli scoring a late winner for the English team. Madrid's increasingly slim hopes were dashed when Mbappé limped off field with an ankle injury with 15 minutes remaining after a clash with Declan Rice.

title: 'Russia has no regard for climate issues'
summary: Under Vladimir Putin's regime, harmful subterranean exploitation projects have multiplied, and Russian greenhouse gas emissions have significantly increased, say historians Laurent Coumel and Marc Elie.

title: Art market: Collectible posters remain affordable
summary: Witnesses to the industrial revolution at the turn of the 19th and 20th centuries, advertising posters, celebrated in an exhibition at the Musée d'Orsay, remain accessible at reasonable prices.

title: Zuckerberg denies Meta bought rivals to conquer them
summary: The co-founder of Facebook, in court on Wednesday, responded 'No' when asked by Meta attorney Mark Hansen if his intent was to eliminate rivals with the purchases of photo-sharing app Instagram and messaging service WhatsApp.

title: California to sue US government over 'self-destructive' Trump tariffs
summary: The case is the latest of more than a dozen lawsuits that California has filed against the Trump administration. Governor Gavin Newsom, until recently, has spent much of the last three months trying to avoid open conflict with Trump due to the need for federal assistance after the fires swept through Los Angeles in January.

title: Island-wide blackout paralyzes Puerto Rico ahead of Easter weekend
summary: Puerto Rico plunged into darkness Wednesday as a sweeping blackout left all 1.4 million customers without power, disrupting Easter travel, shuttering businesses, and reigniting outrage over the island’s fragile energy grid.

title: Sweden falls in love with a novel about growing old
summary: 'When the Cranes Fly South,' the debut novel by a sociology doctoral student, has captivated nearly 200,000 readers in a country of ten million inhabitants, where reading is on the decline. This bestseller is set to be translated into about 30 languages and will be released in France in 2026.

title: In Nepal, widespread discontent fuels calls for the restoration of the monarchy
summary: While the former authoritarian monarch remains controversial, the movement in his favor reflects the frustration of some Nepalis given the instability that has prevailed since the country became a republic in 2008.

title: French prison attacks: Investigators explore all leads, from drug traffickers to the far left
summary: For three nights in a row, coordinated attacks have set vehicles on fire in prison parking lots across the country. One prison even faced heavy weapons fire.

title: Why is it so difficult for France and Algeria to stabilize their relationship?
summary: After a brief respite, the rift between Paris and Algiers was once again reignited by the expulsion of 12 French embassy agents in retaliation for the detention of an employee of the Algerian consulate in Paris.

title: The first time Le Monde wrote 'tiger mosquito'
summary: On La Réunion, the chikungunya epidemic has peaked with more than 33,000 cases and six deaths recorded. Like dengue or Zika, the virus is transmitted by the tiger mosquito. On July 30, 1948, the insect was mentioned for the first time in Le Monde, which has since continued to track its spread.

title: Macron vows French prison attackers will be 'found, tried and punished'
summary: Since Sunday, unknown assailants have targeted several jails and facilities across France, torching cars, spraying the entrance of one prison with automatic fire and leaving mysterious inscriptions.

title: UK Supreme Court rules definition of 'woman' based on sex at birth
summary: Five judges in Britain's top court unanimously ruled on Wednesday that 'the terms 'woman' and 'sex' in the Equality Act 2010 refer to a biological woman, and biological sex.'

title: 'Russian gas and Europe is an old story that ended badly, but Trump seems ready to revive it'
summary: Nord Stream, season 2? The idea of reactivating the pipeline via a US company, as part of ceasefire negotiations in Ukraine, has awoken the German appetite for cheap Russian gas. This project would be devastating for European unity, notes Le Monde columnist Sylvie Kauffmann.

title: What do Russians dream of? Le Monde's photo report on nine ordinary citizens in the shadow of war
summary: After more than three years of war with Ukraine, the voices of Russians, silenced by the Kremlin, remain rare. How do they envision their future and that of their country at a time of new geopolitical shifts? Photographer Mary Gelman collected nine testimonies.
